content: Added "write answer" to stub generator so that the initial default code shows the syntax for debugging and outputting the answer.

(nitpick) "an uniform manner" should be "a uniform manner"
ref: https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/4700/is-it-a-uniform-or-an-uniform
missing intensity's reading in stub ... added

I love the effect! Thanks for the discovery

One question about the usage. If you want to do it in 2 directions, Is there recommandation to start for example by the largest size then the other one? one after each other until you reach your expected size ? Or it doesn't have any impact (for me there is an impact because the lowest energy path will be different for example vertically if you already scaled horizontally) ?

Just about perfect, all I got left is minor nits.
* V isn't very nice a variable name. Something like Target? or W2?
* The PNM link at the beginning of the Input section scared me at first. Better keep it for the end of the section, as the supplementary material it is, not needed for resolution.
* The non-wrappable equations for energy tend to be hidden in my screen setup. Maybe keep constraints and definitions on separate lines?

Anyway, it's good to go as is, approving.
That's something I had in the back of my mind for a while but hadn't come to formalize yet. Thanks for beating me to it! I'll give it a look ASAP.
PS: aaaaaaaaaaw @ T/Vs 5 through 10; T10 looks like an almost-dupe, no? (too lazy to go back and check)

The sequence of horizontal/vertical carvings that you choose has an impact, usually not a huge one though. In general, a randomly alternate strategy seems to give a good result (you could also do it several times and pick the sequence that removes the less energy in total). In the article mentioned in the references, the authors suggest another DP algorithm (section 4.2) to compute the sequence that minimizes the global energy loss.

Oh yeah, thanks (usually I do not add the output as I consider it completely useless, but actually you're right, it at least reminds the syntax for debugging).

Note that ideally it would be something such as:
loop W-V write answer
but expressions ("W-V") seem to be refused by the stub generator.

Thanks!
I chose V as it was kind of a seam-carved W ;-) (yeah, I know...). I kept it for now but I'll change if you insist.
I changed the rest and also added testcases descriptions (completely forgot about that).
I'm not sure to understand your "PS", cases 1&8, 2&5, 3&6, 4&10 are based on the same images, yet with completely different sizes (cases 5 to 10 are the normal tests using 6 distinct images, cases 1 to 4 are the smaller ones reusing 4 smaller versions of 4 of the 6 images, tests/validators are based on 2 completely distinct sets of 6 images).
Then it just meant I recognized T10 as having been there already (as T4 if you say so), but not the others. No matter.
